content.description:
This rig is still cleaning up a bit... we pulled off a big hold today ;) It is kind of an unoriginal name....

Pull up on crimps to a roof, clip a LONG draw to the first bolt, then commit to some reachy moves up and right, following a thin horizontal crack above a roof. Reach left to clip the second bolt, then fire up some sequential compression moves until you reach jugs and a big stance.

The second half of the route is only 5.9 or so and a little dirty, but it has good rock. The route needs a little more traffic! The bouldery first half is really good and worth doing.
content.location:
It is to the right of

Iron Horse

on the NW facing backside of the crag. The first bolt is on the underside of a roof 10' up.

content.description:
Softtail is a ledgy climb with a few exposed moves. It is the left bolt line that follows the corner.

Begin with easy climbing to a high first bolt. This can be protected with a cam if you want to, but it is not too heady.
content.location: It is on the 2nd rock formation (further right from the parking) on the left hand corner of the road-facing wall.

content.description: "Climb the face via lichen covered flakes."
content.location:
This climb is the bolt line to the right of

Crazy Horse

.

content.description: Stem, jam, and crank your way up a left-leaning corner system on positive holds. Great movement ends with a sweet view.
content.location: Up the gully between the 2 Roadside Crags, look right to find an obvious, left-leaning corner.

content.description:
Poker in the Rear is a well-protected, mixed route.

It has about 30 feet of moderate climbing leading to 7 or so bolts of slabby climbing above.

The crack down the middle of the face has many places for mid-sized gear or there are a few different seams you can use on the large flake to the left, although it's a little chossy.

The guidebook has this route at 80', but there wasn't a lot of rope to spare with a 60m, so it's probably closer to 90'.

It is a little bit dirty, but it is a good route! There are lots of different ways/gear you can use at the start.

There is a variation of this route that splits off right after you get over the ledge that leads to a different set of anchors. The variation is also ~5.9 and would be a rope stretcher with a 60m rope.
content.location: From the parking area, it is on the face directly across the road. Scramble up and to the right to the belay ledge.

content.description: Start in the crack system down low before clipping bolts on a vertical face. This is continuous and pumpy.
content.protection: 4 bolts, some small cams to protect the bottom, and coldshut anchors.
content.location: The right side of the wall starts in a slanting crack system. An obvious chickenhead jug can be seen 20 feet off the deck.

content.description: Climb sweet edges and jugs into the corner under the roof. Clip around the roof, and pull through and establish yourself on a rail-type feature and corner (crux). More positive holds and crystal nubs take you to the top.
content.location: It is the obvious steep line going through a small roof and climbing a rounded arete in the middle of the wall.

content.description:
Liquor Up Front is a well-protected, mixed gear and bolt route. The first 30 feet is well protected by cams/wires.

Start as for

Poker in the Rear

, but step right rather than left at the start of the upper slab climbing. Finish on steep jugs to the anchors.
content.protection: 7 bolts, a few cams or nuts, and coldshut anchors.
content.location:
Do the same start as

Poker in the Rear

, and start on a ledge/ sloping dirt behind the large tree/snag.

content.description: Scramble up a slab to a good ledge before entering a shallow crack system just left of a large roof. Work up and left to a rust colored panel of stone beneath a cracked roof. Pull the fabulous roof to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, stoppers, gear to 0.75", and 2 coldshut anchors.
content.location: It is on the far right side of Roadside Crag. Belay in a small rock alcove by a tree.

content.description:
Begin with thin, bouldery moves off the ground - a stickclip is recommended. The second clip is also a bit dicey, so maybe save this until you're solid at the grade.

After that, the climbing mellows a bit, but there is still a move or two up high. This is not the best route on the wall, but it may be worth it if you're here. Crazy Horse is much better, IMO.
content.location: It is the third bolted route from the left just right of a shallow corner and left of a roofy area.

content.description:
This shares a first bolt with

Softtail

and then goes right on steep face climbing with good holds.

The name and grade are unknown.
content.location: It is on the 2nd rock formation (further right from the parking) on the left hand corner of the road-facing wall.

climbs.name: Crotch Rocket
climbs.fa: M. Laggis, J. Barr-Laggis, and S. Johnson

content.description:
Work up the broken face using positive ledges galore. This shares anchors with

Rice Rocket

.
content.location:
It is up the gully between the 2 crags, past New Climb arete, and directly left of

Rice Rocket

.

content.description: The start is up a steep face, and the crux is through a bulge using a pinch, undercling move.
content.protection: 5 bolts, cams to 3", and a 2-bolt anchor.
